chatgpt_double_star.new_statement: A durable reform should make the winner track the national popular will more reliably while keeping states central to administering elections and preserving incentives to campaign across regions. A realistic path is to curb winner-take-all—through proportional elector allocation or an interstate compact that awards electors to the national vote winner—paired with consistent nationwide rules for voter access, ballot counting, audits, and recount triggers. Add guardrails like limiting faithless electors and considering an expanded House to reduce extreme population distortions, so results are transparent, predictable, and broadly accepted.

chatgpt_double_star_rankings.new_statement: Reform should make presidential outcomes track the national popular will more reliably while preserving a meaningful role for states and avoiding a system that lets a few swing states dominate. A workable bridge is to end winner-take-all by requiring proportional (or fair district-based) allocation of electors, and to adopt the National Popular Vote Interstate Compact as a backstop once participating states reach a majority of electoral votes. Pair any change with clear, uniform national standards for ballot access, counting, audits, and recounts, and consider ranked-choice voting to ensure the winner has broad support and improve legitimacy.

chatgpt_double_star_personas.new_statement: Any reform should make presidential elections track the will of voters more closely while keeping states meaningfully involved so rural and smaller communities aren’t written off. A practical middle-ground is to end winner-take-all by allocating electors proportionally (or by district with anti-gerrymandering guardrails), paired with uniform national standards for ballot access, counting, audits, and recounts so results are transparent and trusted. States that want to go further could join the National Popular Vote Interstate Compact, but changes should be phased in and built for broad buy-in, not partisan advantage.
